title: Embolic Stroke of Undetermined Source (ESUS) Criteria
description: Diagnostic criteria for identifying embolic stroke of undetermined source after comprehensive evaluation excluding other specific stroke etiologies.

parameters.name: stroke_type_non_lacunar
parameters.description: Non-lacunar stroke detected by CT or MRI (lacunar defined as subcortical infarct ≤1.5 cm or ≤2.0 cm on MRI diffusion images)

parameters.name: no_significant_atherosclerosis
parameters.description: Absence of extracranial or intracranial atherosclerosis causing ≥50% luminal stenosis in arteries supplying the area of ischemia

parameters.name: no_major_cardioembolic_source
parameters.description: No major cardioembolic sources identified (atrial fibrillation, intracardiac thrombus, prosthetic valve, cardiac tumors, mitral stenosis, recent MI <4 weeks, LVEF <30%, valvular vegetations, infective endocarditis)

parameters.name: no_other_specific_cause
parameters.description: No other specific cause of stroke identified (arteritis, dissection, migraine/vasospasm, drug misuse, genetic disorders)

parameters.name: adequate_cardiac_monitoring
parameters.description: Cardiac rhythm monitoring for ≥24 hours with automated rhythm detection completed

parameters.name: adequate_vascular_imaging
parameters.description: Adequate vascular imaging completed (catheter angiography, MR/CT angiography, or cervical duplex plus transcranial Doppler ultrasonography)

parameters.name: adequate_cardiac_imaging
parameters.description: Adequate cardiac imaging completed (transthoracic echocardiography and/or transesophageal echocardiography)

result.name: esus_diagnosis
result.description: ESUS diagnostic determination based on criteria fulfillment

ranges.interpretation: Patient meets all diagnostic criteria for Embolic Stroke of Undetermined Source (ESUS). This diagnosis applies when all four clinical criteria are satisfied AND adequate diagnostic evaluation has been completed. Consider anticoagulation strategies, extended cardiac monitoring, and targeted embolic source investigation. Patient may be eligible for ESUS-specific clinical trials and treatment protocols.

Patient does not meet diagnostic criteria for Embolic Stroke of Undetermined Source (ESUS). Either clinical criteria are not fulfilled or adequate diagnostic evaluation is incomplete. Complete recommended diagnostic evaluation and identify specific stroke etiology. Consider alternative stroke classifications such as large artery atherosclerosis, cardioembolic stroke, small vessel disease, or other determined etiology.

Diagnostic evaluation is inadequate to determine ESUS status. Complete the minimum required diagnostic evaluation including: ≥24-hour cardiac monitoring with automated rhythm detection, comprehensive vascular imaging of extracranial and intracranial arteries, and adequate cardiac imaging (TTE and/or TEE). Reassess ESUS criteria after completing appropriate diagnostic workup.

references: Hart RG, Diener HC, Coutts SB, Easton JD, Granger CB, O'Donnell MJ, et al. Embolic strokes of undetermined source: the case for a new clinical construct. Lancet Neurol. 2014;13(4):429-38. doi: 10.1016/S1474-4422(13)70310-7.

Ntaios G, Papavasileiou V, Milionis H, Makaritsis K, Manios E, Spengos K, et al. Embolic strokes of undetermined source in the Athens stroke registry: an outcome analysis. Stroke. 2015;46(8):2087-93. doi: 10.1161/STROKEAHA.115.009334.

formula: ESUS diagnosis requires ALL criteria to be met: (1) Non-lacunar stroke on imaging, (2) No significant atherosclerosis (≥50% stenosis), (3) No major cardioembolic source, (4) No other specific stroke cause, AND adequate diagnostic evaluation completed.
notes: ESUS represents 15-25% of all ischemic strokes, with higher prevalence in younger patients.
Lacunar stroke is defined as subcortical infarct ≤1.5 cm (≤2.0 cm on MRI diffusion images) in small penetrating artery distribution.

Major cardioembolic sources include: permanent/paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, sustained atrial flutter, intracardiac thrombus, prosthetic cardiac valve, atrial myxoma, mitral stenosis, recent MI (<4 weeks), LVEF <30%, valvular vegetations, infective endocarditis.

Minimum diagnostic evaluation requires: 12-lead ECG, ≥24-hour cardiac monitoring with automated rhythm detection, echocardiography (TTE and/or TEE), vascular imaging of both extracranial and intracranial arteries.
Vascular imaging methods include catheter angiography, MR/CT angiography, or cervical duplex plus transcranial Doppler ultrasonography.
Other specific causes to exclude: arteritis, dissection, migraine/vasospasm, drug misuse, genetic disorders, hypercoagulable states.
ESUS patients tend to be younger (mean age 65) with milder strokes (mean NIHSS 5) compared to other stroke subtypes.
Stroke recurrence rate in ESUS is approximately 4.5% per year, similar to cardioembolic stroke.
Extended cardiac monitoring (>24 hours) may detect paroxysmal atrial fibrillation in 5-15% of ESUS patients.
The term ESUS replaced 'cryptogenic stroke' to provide standardized criteria for clinical trials and research.
ESUS criteria enable enrollment in specific clinical trials investigating anticoagulation strategies.
Patients meeting ESUS criteria may benefit from extended cardiac monitoring, cardiac MRI, or genetic testing.
The diagnosis has implications for secondary stroke prevention strategies and treatment selection.
ESUS classification facilitates targeted research into stroke mechanisms and therapeutic interventions.
Regular reassessment may be needed as new diagnostic technologies become available.
The criteria should be applied only after completion of adequate diagnostic evaluation as defined.
ESUS diagnosis does not preclude investigation of rare or uncommon stroke etiologies when clinically indicated.
